“For instance, I might name my high level folder Andromeda Galaxy,” Jones describes. “Within that folder I will have a folder named for the year, then inside of that a folder for the month, and it keeps going down until the day. Inside the day, I will have folders for the different frame types. It might seem like overkill the first couple of times that you go out, but in three years, that structure will be much easier to manage.”

Once you have an organized folder structure, import your RAW light frames into Lightroom.

“There’s no better way to look over the light frames than in a software like Lightroom, where you can see all of your exposures in one place and quickly click through them,” Jones notes.

This is where the essential task of culling happens. Jones recommends that you carefully inspect each light frame using Lightroom’s viewing tools. “Zoom in to check for sharp, round stars,” he says, “and reject any with significant trailing from tracking errors or bumps. Discard frames compromised by passing clouds, airplanes, or other unexpected anomalies. You wouldn’t want to include those in your final image stack, so using Lightroom to weed out those unusable images while getting a bird’s eye view of all of the exposures you’ve taken is critical.” Jones suggests using Lightroom’s flagging or rating system to mark the keepers.

It’s vital to understand what not to do at this stage. “There is a big misconception about deep sky astrophotography,” Jones warns. “A lot of people think you need to make edits to the photos before they go into the Image Stacking software, but that is not what you want to do.” The goal in Lightroom before stacking is purely organization and quality control — identifying and removing bad frames. Resist the urge to apply creative edits or even micro-adjustments. “You need to leave the photos in their raw format, stack them and then you do your editing after you have your stacked image stack.” Once you’ve culled your light frames in Lightroom, you’re ready to load those selected RAW files, along with your calibration files, into your chosen stacking software.

Editing Your Stacked Deep-Sky Image: Initial Adjustments in Lightroom

After stacking your light and calibration frames, you’ll have a “master” image file, often in TIFF format, ready for editing. This is where you begin revealing the hidden color and details of your deep-sky target. While foundational adjustments can certainly be made directly in Lightroom, Jones, often recognized in the community for his deep dives into Adobe Photoshop, frequently turns to Photoshop for his processing workflow. For those crucial first steps on the stacked image, he often relies on the powerful Adobe Camera Raw (ACR) plugin within Photoshop.

“ACR is essentially the same engine that powers Lightroom’s Develop module,” Jones clarifies. “So, whether you start in Lightroom or open your file through ACR in Photoshop, you have access to the same fantastic tools to make some pretty important initial adjustments to the image. You can really control everything from your exposure to contrast and clarity to color correction.”

For beginners tackling their first stacked deep-sky image, whether in Lightroom or ACR, Jones suggests focusing on fundamental adjustments. Your stacked image will likely look very dark initially, however Jones says you should not be discouraged. Start by setting the White Balance — choosing a neutral area of background sky can help achieve natural colors. Next, gently adjust Exposure and Contrast sliders, watching the histogram to begin “stretching” the data and revealing faint details without clipping blacks or whites.

Color adjustments are next. “The color mixer is my absolute favorite,” Jones shares. “This is where I increase the saturation of the blues and bring down any of the browns, which is a very common color practice in astrophotography.” Use the HSL/Color panel (available in both Lightroom and ACR) to selectively enhance the specific colors present in your nebula or galaxy.

Noise reduction is crucial. “Noise is always going to be there even if you’ve got five hours of exposure time,” Jones notes, because the stretching process amplifies it along with the faint signal. Jones says that Lightroom’s Noise Reduction tools in the Detail panel (Luminance, Color, and AI Denoise) are very effective, and similar controls are available in ACR. “The color noise reduction tool is my favorite,” he says. “It allows me to move that slider up, reducing a serious amount of noise, however, my primary target isn’t overly smoothed out and soft looking. For me, it’s kind of a balance between detail and noise reduction.”

Finally, tools like Clarity and Texture can subtly enhance details, but Jones advises caution. “Anything that controls the contrast can become very unnatural looking if you take that too far in astrophotography images, so apply these very gently,” he advises.

While more complex edits involving layers and masks typically happen later in the Photoshop process, mastering these initial adjustments in Lightroom or Adobe Camera Raw is a vital first step in bringing your deep-sky images to life.

Deep-Sky Astrophotography: Embracing the Learning Curve and the Journey

Deep-sky astrophotography is undeniably complex, blending technical skill with artistic vision. The editing stage offers flexibility, says Jones. “You can get a big cup of coffee on a Saturday morning and spend so much time watching tutorials and stacking and then editing your photos in Lightroom,” he says.

However, he notes that the image acquisition phase often presents the steepest learning curve. “When you’re outside and you’ve got three hours of clear night and you’re trying to get your gear to work together successfully, that’s where the pressure and frustrations can come in,” Jones acknowledges.

He stresses that persistence and practice are paramount. “Get out every clear night you can and play with your gear and have really humble expectations of your results, at least in the early stages. The only way to get better at deep sky astrophotography is through repetition.”

This journey of learning and overcoming challenges is, for Jones, central to the appeal of the hobby. He found his own passion not just in the final images, but in the dedication required to capture them. “My love for deep sky astrophotography is centered on the chase and the amount of effort that you have to put into it,” he shares. “The more effort and the more struggles I face, the more rewarding it is when I finally see it come alive on my screen.” He adds that it’s a pursuit that demands patience and pushes photographers to constantly learn and adapt.

Beyond the technical hurdles lies a deeper connection. “Astronomy sparked a new appreciation for the natural world around me, and the experience of simply being under the stars is profound. The feeling of spending a night under the Milky Way is like no other,” he describes. This sense of wonder fuels the dedication required. “The experience of being out there on a perfect spring night, standing under the stars, watching your camera collecting these images, and getting excited about finally seeing the final picture is a feeling that is hard to match,” he says.

“When you combine that feeling with the realization you’re capturing galaxies millions of light-years away, it’s mind blowing.”

For those who truly catch the astrophotography bug, Jones believes, the entire process becomes captivating. “You’re going to love everything about it: the setup, the noises you hear, how the stars overtake the entire sky as your eyes adjust to the darkness. It’s just an incredible feeling, and an incredible passion, that I will never stop loving.”
